DataElement.preferredName: Diagnostic Imaging Baseline Iobenguane Avidity Disease or Disorder Positive Finding Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator of whether or not patient has confirmed MIBG avid disease or disorder.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Diagnostic Imaging Baseline Iobenguane Avidity Disease or Disorder Positive Finding
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation._A starting point to which things may be compared._A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells._Strength of binding, usually of a small molecule with multiple binding sites by a larger, particularly the binding of a complex antigen by an antibody._Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function._A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation..

Concepts.definition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation.

Property.preferredName: Baseline Iobenguane Avidity Disease or Disorder Positive Finding
Property.preferredDefinition: A starting point to which things may be compared.:A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.:Strength of binding, usually of a small molecule with multiple binding sites by a larger, particularly the binding of a complex antigen by an antibody.:Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.:A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Concepts.definition: A starting point to which things may be compared.

A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.
Strength of binding, usually of a small molecule with multiple binding sites by a larger, particularly the binding of a complex antigen by an antibody.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.
A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
